Fig. 1 XRPD patterns of the unreduced forms of the prepared materials. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 XRPD patterns of the reduced forms of the prepared materials. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Hydrogen desorption profiles for: a) cerium promoted; b) cerium and barium promoted cobalt catalysts. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Studies of the reducibility of catalysts precursors prepared with the use of different precipitating agent: a) derivative mass loss (DTG); b) MS signal of water (MSH2O). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 The ratio of a reaction rate (expressed in gNH3 cmcat −3 h−1) units) over the promoted ruthenium catalyst [34] or promoted cobalt catalyst [19] to the rate of reaction over the industrial iron catalyst [19] in the function of NH3 content in the gas phase (conditions of NH3 synthesis reaction rate measurements: T=400°C, p=6.3MPa, H2/N2 =3:1). Fig. 5 Table 1 Composition of prepared materials. Table 1 Symbol Precipitant Composition of sample Co(OH)2Ce(OH)3 KOH a mixture of cobalt and cerium hydroxides oxidesCoCe(KOH) a mixture of cobalt and cerium oxides redCoCe(KOH) metallic cobalt and active forms of Ce promoter preCoCeBa(KOH) a mixture of cobalt and cerium oxides impregnated by barium nitrite catCoCeBa(KOH) metallic cobalt and active forms of Ce and Ba promoters CoCO3Ce(CO3)3 K2CO3 a mixture of cobalt and cerium carbonates oxidesCoCe(K2CO3) a mixture of cobalt and cerium oxides redCoCe(K2CO3) metallic cobalt and active forms of Ce promoter preCoCeBa(K2CO3) a mixture of cobalt and cerium oxides impregnated by barium nitrite catCoCeBa(K2CO3) metallic cobalt and active forms of Ce and Ba promoters Table 2 The content of the individual components in the obtained precursors. Table 2 Symbol wt% Co3O4 wt% CeO2 wt% Ba a wt% K2O b preCoCeBa(KOH) 76.1 12.6 9.9 undetectable preCoCeBa(K2CO3) 77.3 13.3 8.4 undetectable a barium was introduced in the form Ba(NO2)2. b K2O content in the samples were below the limit of quantification by the XRF method (less than 0.05wt%). Table 3 Textural characteristics of the unreduced form of obtained materials. Feature Article Effect of precipitating agent on the properties of cobalt catalysts promoted with cerium and barium for NH3 synthesis obtained by co-precipitation Aleksandra Tarka a Magdalena Zybert a Zuzanna Kindler a Jacek Szmurło a Bogusław Mierzwa b Wioletta Raróg-Pilecka a ⁎ a Warsaw University of Technology, Faculty of Chemistry, Noakowskiego 3, 00-664, Warsaw, Poland Warsaw University of Technology Faculty of Chemistry Noakowskiego 3 Warsaw 00-664 Poland b Institute of Physical Chemistry, Polish Academy of Sciences, Kasprzaka 44/52, 01-224, Warsaw, Poland Institute of Physical Chemistry Polish Academy of Sciences Kasprzaka 44/52 Warsaw 01-224 Poland ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Cobalt catalysts singly promoted with cerium and doubly promoted with cerium and barium were prepared by co-precipitation using different precipitating agents, i.e. potassium hydroxide or potassium carbonate, subsequent calcination and impregnation. The obtained materials were characterized at each step of preparation using selected techniques: X-ray fluorescence (XRF), N2 physisorption, X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD), temperature-programmed reduction coupled with mass spectrometry (TPR-MS) and temperature-programmed hydrogen desorption (H2-TPD). The activity in ammonia synthesis was measured also under conditions close to the industrial ones (T=400–470°C, p=6.3MPa, H2/N2 =3:1). The materials obtained with the use of K2CO3 as a precipitant have better textural parameters (smaller Co3O4 crystallites) than the analogous materials obtained with the use of KOH. The differences in textural properties of the materials derived from KOH or K2CO3 as a precipitant decrease with a progress of catalysts preparation and finally the active phase surface area of the catalysts promoted with cerium and barium is similar. Regardless of the precipitating agent used the surface activities (TOF) and NH3 synthesis reaction rates for these catalysts are nearly the same. However, the TOF values for the doubly promoted catalysts are about one order of magnitude higher than that for the catalysts promoted only with cerium. Therefore, it seems that not a type of precipitating agent used during preparation, but a composition of the studied promoted cobalt catalysts is more important factor influencing the activity of these catalytic systems. Keywords Ammonia synthesis Cobalt catalyst Catalyst preparation Co-precipitation Precipitating agent 1 Introduction Catalysis plays a crucial role in the chemical industry, because the use of a catalyst allows to reduce the activation energy and to increase the reaction rate. A catalyst should be capable to conduct the process with the highest efficiency and with the lowest energy consumption at the same time. Therefore, the main factor in a selection of a catalyst for an industrial process is its activity and process costs resulting from the use of the catalyst. An equally important issue is a catalyst preparation, because a choice of a method and preparation conditions determines subsequent properties of a catalyst. One of the most widely used methods of industrial heterogeneous catalysts preparation is precipitation [1–3]. It is a simple method, which seems to be straightforward to scale-up, but in practice it may cause some difficulties [4]. Important factors such as temperature, pH of solutions, a precursor of an active phase, a precipitating agent or aging time may affect properties of final catalytic materials [5]. One of the first and one of the most important processes using a heterogeneous catalyst is ammonia synthesis. A fused iron with promoters addition is most commonly used as a catalyst to this process [6–8]. Ruthenium supported on activated carbon [8–12] is also known and used in industrial ammonia synthesis plants. Until 2013 it was applied in only ten plants in the world [8] and studies on new potential catalytic systems are still ongoing. Co-containing catalysts became the subject of research towards the use in ammonia synthesis, e.g. Fe-Co [13,14], Co-Mo-N [15–17] and Co-Ce-Ba systems [18,19]. These last mentioned Co-catalysts prepared by co-precipitation exhibit in NH3 synthesis higher activity than the commercial KM I iron catalyst (H. Topsøe) [19]. In our previous studies [20] it has been found that among the tested groups of selected carbonates and hydroxides the most effective precipitating agents for the co-precipitated Co-Ce-Ba catalysts are potassium carbonate and potassium hydroxide, respectively. The aim of this work was the deeper insight into the effect of precipitating agent on catalytic properties of the co-precipitated cobalt catalysts by the detailed characterization of the obtained materials at each step of their preparation (co-precipitation and drying, calcination, impregnation by barium, reduction). X-ray fluorescence (XRF), nitrogen physisorption, X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD), temperature-programmed reduction coupled with mass spectrometry (TPR-MS) and temperature-programmed hydrogen desorption (H2-TPD) have been employed to explore the relationship between the precipitating agent and Co-Ce-Ba catalysts activity tested in NH3 synthesis reaction under conditions close to the industrial ones. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation Cobalt catalysts singly promoted with cerium and doubly promoted with cerium and barium were prepared by co-precipitation using different precipitating agents, i.e. potassium hydroxide or potassium carbonate, subsequent calcination and impregnation according to the procedure described previously [19]. Briefly, mixtures of cobalt and cerium hydroxides or cobalt and cerium carbonates were co-precipitated using potassium hydroxide or potassium carbonate as a precipitating agent, respectively. The obtained precipitates were filtered under reduced pressure (0.04MPa) and washed with cold distilled water several times until the pH was neutral, in order to remove residual K+, CO3 2− and NO3 − ions. The materials were then dried at 120°C and then calcined at 500°C in air to mixtures of cobalt and cerium oxides. Next they were impregnated by an aqueous solution of barium nitrite (incipient wetness impregnation) and dried at 120°C. Samples of the precursors were crushed and sieved to get a grain of 0.20–0.63mm in size. The final step of preparation was a reduction of catalysts precursors carried out directly before the measurements requiring a reduced form of the materials (temperature-programmed hydrogen desorption and catalytic activity measurements). A short description of the materials composition and symbols of the samples was listed in Table 1 . At the end of symbols (in brackets) the precipitating agent used during the co-precipitation was indicated. A percentage composition of the obtained catalysts precursors determined by XRF method is presented in Table 2 . The content of all components is similar in both obtained materials, regardless of the type of precipitating agent used, and is optimal for cobalt catalysts precursors. Moreover, K2O content in the samples were below the limit of quantification by XRF method (less than 0.05wt%) in both doubly promoted cobalt catalysts, which indicates that potassium ions were removed effectively from the precipitates during washing process. 2.2 Characterization techniques The content of components i.e. compounds of cobalt, cerium and barium in the final catalysts precursors was determined by wavelength dispersive X-ray fluorescence spectrometry using ARL™ PERFORM'X. The spectrometer equipped with a rhodium lamp with a maximum power of excitation of 4.2kW was used. Nitrogen physisorption measurements using ASAP 2020 (Micromeritics Instrument Co.) were used to determine a specific surface area and total pore volume of all the prepared materials. Before the analysis, samples were subjected to two-stage degassing for 1h and then 4h at properly selected temperatures: 50°C and 80°C for Co(OH)2Ce(OH)3 and CoCO3Ce(CO3)3, 90°C and 200°C for oxidesCoCe(KOH), oxidesCoCe(K2CO3), catCoCeBa(KOH) and catCoCeBa(K2CO3), 90°C and 150°C for preCoCeBa(KOH) and preCoCeBa(K2CO3). A specific surface area (SBET) and a total pore volume (Vpor) were determined using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) adsorption isotherm models, respectively. XRPD analysis was performed in order to identify phase composition of the materials in both unreduced and reduced form. Data were collected with a Rigaku-Denki (Geigerflex) diffractometer in Brag-Brentano configuration with CuKα radiation. Powder samples of the materials were scanned in a 2θ range equals 15–100° with step of 0.02° and counting time 5s. An average size of crystallites was estimated based on the Scherrer equation using the integral width of reflection fitted to the analytical Pearson VII function. TPR-MS experiments were conducted to monitor of the materials reduction. The measurements were carried out using STA 449C thermobalance equipped with a quadrupole mass spectrometer QMS Äeolos 403C (Netzsch). About 15mg of samples were heated from room temperature to 600°C at a rate of 10° min−1 and then were maintained at the temperature for 2h. A gas mixture of H2/Ar (10% H2 by volume, gas flow rate 100mlmin−1) as a reductant was used. The mass change, temperature and MS signal of water (m/e=18) were monitored during the experiments. H2-TPD measurements were carried out using fully automated AutoChem 2920 (Micromeritics Instrument Co.) in a flow set-up supplied with high purity (99.99995 vol%) gases (total gas flow rate 40mlmin−1) in a quartz U-tube reactor. The detailed experimental procedure was described previously [21]. Before the measurement samples of catalysts precursors containing 0.4g Co3O4 were reduced in H2 flow at 550°C for 18h. Next, temperature was raised up to 570°C in Ar flow and a measuring system was irrigated by Ar for about 1h and cooled to 150°C after that. At that temperature the H2 adsorption was carried out for 15min. In the next step the adsorption had been continued during cooling the sample to 0°C and then at 0°C for 15min. Next the system was flushed with Ar (0°C) to remove weakly bound molecules of H2 and temperature was raised at a constant rate (10°Cmin−1) to 550°C and then kept for 25min while monitoring the concentration of hydrogen desorbing from the surface of the catalyst. The hydrogen uptake value was used, subsequently, for determining (i) the dispersion of cobalt, expressed as the fraction of cobalt atoms exposed (FE) and (ii) the size of cobalt crystallites (dCo). The H:Cosurface =1:1 stoichiometry of adsorption [22] was assumed to recalculate the value of hydrogen uptake into the FE value. The generalized equation proposed in [23] was applied in the dCo calculations: d Co = 5 .01 ⋅ d at FE f o r F E < 0.2 where dCo is the size of cobalt crystallites, dat is the atomic diameter of cobalt (2.51∙10−10 m) and FE is the fraction of cobalt atoms exposed to hydrogen. The equation has been derived for a closepacked metal structure assuming that the crystallites form cubooctaedrons or icosaedrons (similar to spherical shape). The surface area of an active phase (metallic cobalt) available for hydrogen (SCo) was calculated based on dCo values, density of metallic cobalt (ρCo =8.9∙106 gm−3) and according to the assumption about sphericity of cobalt crystallites. 2.3 Catalytic activity tests A catalysts activity in ammonia synthesis was tested in an integral reactor operating with a stoichiometric high purity H2-N2 mixture in inlet gas. A detailed description of the set-up has been described in [24]. The concentration of ammonia in the outlet gas stream was determined interferometrically. The measurements of activity were performed at 400, 430 and 470°C, at a constant pressure of 6.3MPa and gas flow rate 70dm3(STP) h−1. Samples of catalyst precursors containing about 0.5g Co3O4 were reduced directly before the activity measurements in a high purity H2/N2 =3:1 mixture (99.99995vol%, gas flow rate 10dm3(STP) h−1), under atmospheric pressure at temperatures 470°C for 72h, then 520°C for 24h and finally 550°C for 48h. Such conditions of an activation process are optimal, because they lead to the highest activity of the cobalt catalysts. After the activity test, cerium and barium promoted catalysts catCoCeBa(X) were overheated under atmospheric pressure and gas flow rate of H2-N2 30dm3(STP)h−1 at 600°C by 16h. The activity of samples was measured again after that. The rate of NH3 synthesis was calculated from a mass balance for a catalyst layer according to the equation: r av = x ( 1+x ) ⋅ m ⋅ 17 .03 22 .08 ⋅ V 0 where rav is an average reaction rate ( g NH3 gCo −1 h−1), x are the content of NH3 (molar fraction) in the outlet gas, m is the mass of metallic cobalt in the catalyst sample (g), 17.03 and 22.08 are constant values relevant to the molar mass of ammonia (gmol−1) and the molar volume of a stoichiometric mixture of synthesis gas H2-N2 (dm3(STP) h−1), respectively, and V0 is the flow rate of synthesis gas (dm3(STP) h−1). The xav conversion values were calculated from an equation: x av = x 2 . 3 Results and discussion The physisorption data of the materials before the reduction (Table 3 ) indicates that the use of potassium carbonate as a precipitant allows to obtained the materials of better textural parameters than these obtained with the use of potassium hydroxide. Specific surface areas of CoCO3Ce(CO3)3 and the materials obtained from it are about 4-fold higher than in the case of the analogous materials derived from Co(OH)2Ce(OH)3. However, SBET and Vpor values for both types of the materials decrease at the following stages of the catalysts preparation, which can result from grains sintering and a partial clogging of materials pores by barium salt. Fig. 1 presents the diffraction patterns of the cobalt-cerium oxides (oxidesCoCe(X)) and the precursors of catalysts (preCoCeBa(X)) obtained with the use of K2CO3 or KOH. Two phases: Co3O4 and CeO2 are visible in oxidesCoCe(KOH) and oxidesCoCe(K2CO3) samples. In the case of preCoCeBa(KOH) and preCoCeBa(K2CO3) materials also signals derived from BaCO3 phase are observed. Based on the results of XRPD measurements an average size of cobalt oxide crystallites ( d X-Co 3 O 4 ) in the samples was estimated and a specific surface area ( S X-Co 3 O 4 ) of the studied materials was calculated. All the obtained values are listed in Table 3. As seen, the XRPD data ( S X-Co 3 O 4 values) are in a good agreement with the results of N2 physisorption measurements ( S P-Co 3 O 4 values) – the surface area of the samples obtained with the use of K2CO3 as a precipitant is higher than the surface of the analogous materials obtained with the use of KOH. The diffraction patterns of the reduced materials (redCoCe(X) and catCoCeBa(X)), after catalytic activity measurements are presented in Fig. 2 . In all of these patterns metallic Co and CeO2 phases are visible and additional phases of CoO and Ba(CeO3) appear in the case of redCoCe(X) and catCoCeBa(X) catalysts, respectively. CoO phase occurrence indicates a partial oxidation of cobalt as a result of contact of the samples with air (ex situ XRPD measurements). Face centered cubic (fcc) and hexagonal close packed (hcp) structures of metallic cobalt coexist in the studied materials. The signals at the 2θ angle of 41.7° and 47.5° typical for hcp phase of cobalt are visible. They refer to (100) and (101) plane of cobalt, respectively. The only reflection attributed to fcc phase alone ((200) plane) appears around 2θ of 51.6°. The other signals, at 2θ of 44.4°, 75.9° and 92.4° may result from the presence of the two phases. It may suggest the coexistence of both hcp and fcc phases or the presence of polytypic structure of cobalt in the materials. Polytypism occurs when two or more layer-like crystal structures that differ in layer stacking sequences coexist in a compound [25]. A random shift from hcp to fcc or fcc to hcp ordering occurs in polytypic structure of cobalt. The following effects may prove the occurrence of the polytypic Co structure: (1) a coexistence of both (hcp and fcc) phases, (2) an elevated background in the area of reflections of high intensity, (3) a lack of some typical reflections and (4) a disturbance of the ratio of the intensity of reflections corresponding to pure hcp or fcc phases. Some of these effects were observed in the studied catalytic materials. According to Crystallography Open Database (COD) the theoretical ratio of the intensity of reflections derived from (100) and (101) planes of hcp phase and (100) hcp and (200) fcc planes are 0.3 and 0.6, respectively. The values of these ratios estimated for the reduced form of the prepared materials are listed in Table 3. It can be seen that for redCoCe(K2CO3) and catCoCeBa(KOH) samples the calculated ratios are close to the theoretical, which may indicate the presence of pure hcp and fcc phases separately in these materials. In turn, the ratios obtained for redCoCe(KOH) and catCoCeBa(K2CO3) samples are far from the theoretical values and this may indicate the presence of polytypic structure of cobalt in these materials. Additionally, raised background is observed for 2θ angles in the range of 40–53° on XRPD patterns – Fig. 2. It may result from at least three reasons: (1) the presence of an amorphous cobalt in the materials, (2) the presence of the cobalt oxide phase (ex situ measurements), and (3) polytypism, which was determined in some of the materials. For reduced forms of the studied materials the average size of the stacks of planes, attributed to the individual phases were estimated and listed in Table 4 as a size parameter. It is clearly seen that the average sizes of the stacks of planes corresponding to samples obtained from the mixture of cobalt and cerium hydroxides are higher than in the case of materials obtained from the mixture of cobalt and cerium carbonates as a precursor. Fig. 3 a and b present curves of hydrogen desorption from the surface of the redCoCe(X) and catCoCeBa(X) catalysts, respectively. In H2 desorption profiles for cerium promoted cobalt catalysts – redCoCe(X), only one broad peak is visible (see Fig. 3a). It can be observed that the total intensity of signal for redCoCe(KOH) is about twice smaller than for redCoCe(K2CO3). In the case of doubly promoted cobalt catalyst catCoCeBa(X), the total intensities of H2 desorption signals seem to be similar in both catCoCeBa(KOH) and catCoCeBa(K2CO3) samples (see Fig. 3b). Moreover, two peaks are observed for these catalysts in comparison to the samples containing only cerium promoter. The first peak with a maximum at about 120°C for catCoCeBa(KOH) and for catCoCeBa(K2CO3) corresponds to desorption of H2 weakly bound to the surface of cobalt (low-temperature peak). Whereas the second peak with a maximum at 490°C for both catalysts is associated with the desorption of H2 strongly interacting with the surface of the active phase (high-temperature peak). Interestingly, profiles of hydrogen desorption for catalysts promoted with cerium and barium slightly differ from each other. The low-temperature peak is more intensive for catCoCeBa(K2CO3) than for catCoCeBa(KOH) whereas the high-temperature peak is more intensive for catCoCeBa(KOH) than for catCoCeBa(K2CO3). The average size of cobalt crystallite (dCo) and a specific surface area of an active phase (SCo) of catalysts determined based on H2-TPD measurements results are presented in Table 4. The SCo values of samples without barium differ from each other – redCoCe(K2CO3) has over twice higher surface of an active phase than redCoCe(KOH). Barium addition causes that the average Co crystallite sizes are similar for both of the materials. However, the dCo values obtained on the basis of H2 chemisorption measurements are significantly higher than in the case of the average size of the stacks of planes estimated based on XRPD analysis. This discrepancy could be due to the fact that small cobalt crystallites are detectable by XRPD and its size can be estimated, but they can create larger clusters and only the external, much smaller area of these clusters is available for hydrogen during TPD measurement, so they are consider as one larger crystallite. Nevertheless, it is worth to point out that the dCo values for individual materials, which were obtained from various precursors, are in good agreement with the XRPD results. The results of the TPR-MS experiments, conducted to determine reduction properties of the studied materials are shown in Fig. 4 a and b. The first derivative of mass loss (DTG curve – Fig. 4a) and the amount of evolved water (MSH2O – Fig. 4b) is depicted as a function of time. A mass loss observed during the reduction process is associated mainly with two-step reduction of Co3O4 to Co [26,27] and Ba(NO2)2 decomposition and a reduction of nitrite ions. In the case of oxidesCoCe(K2CO3) two separated peaks are observed in the temperature range of about 200–330°C and 360–600°C (Fig. 4a). Both of them correspond to two peaks on the mass signal of water (Fig. 4b). The first peak is related to the Co3O4 reduction to CoO and the second corresponds to the further reduction of CoO to metallic Co. In the case of oxidesCoCe(KOH) the second signal is placed closer to the first one, whereby the whole reduction ends sooner, i.e. at 470°C (see Fig. 4a and b). Effects associated with the decomposition and the reduction of Ba(NO2)2 in the reduction curves of preCoCeBa(X) precursors are visible. In the case of preCoCeBa(K2CO3) an additional peak with a maximum at 200°C occurs. Whereas the last peak became sharper than the analogous signal observed for oxidesCoCe(K2CO3) and its maximum is shifted to higher temperatures, but it is difficult to univocally determine, which peaks correspond to specific reactions. However, based on our previous studies (data not presented) it can be assumed that at 200°C and 500°C Ba(NO2)2 transition occurs. Additionally, the peak with the maximum at 500°C corresponds with the further reduction of CoO too. In the case of preCoCeBa(KOH) peaks are not clearly separated. A simultaneous reduction of Co3O4 and Ba(NO2)2 to its active forms takes place in the same temperature range and ends later than oxidesCoCe(KOH) (at 520°C). The most important conclusion, which results from the presented studies is that the reduction of materials obtained from the mixture of hydroxide as a precursor (oxidesCoCe(KOH) and preCoCeBa(KOH)) ends sooner than the reduction of materials obtained from CoCO3Ce2(CO3)3 (oxidesCoCe(K2CO3) and preCoCeBa(K2CO3)). The easier reduction of the former samples may be due to a larger size of cobalt oxide crystallites ( d p − C o 3 O 4 ) (Table 3) as it is indicated in the literature by Khodakov [28] and Martínez [29]. However, their studies refer to the Co-supported catalysts. Khodakov tried to explain that the interaction between the support and smaller metal particles is stronger than in the case of larger ones. As a result smaller particles are harder to reduce. On the other hand, the reduction studies of the unsupported Co3O4 [30] have shown that the reduction occurs slower when Co3O4 particles are larger. It raises the question about the role of cerium oxide in the obtained catalysts. The previous studies [18,19] showed that CeO2 acts as a structural promoter − ceria addition causes the increase of Co3O4 dispersion (cobalt oxide forms smaller crystallites). The delayed reduction of Co3O4 to metallic Co is observed at the same time, because ceria uptakes additional hydrogen on the reduction of surface oxygen spacies [31,32]. This phenomenon occurs easier (i.e. at lower temperatures) in the presence of cobalt as a result of the hydrogen spillover from Co to CeO2. The H2 spillover effect becomes stronger with increasing surface of cobalt, i.e. when cobalt oxide particles are smaller. More hydrogen is consumed and a longer time is required to a total reduction of cobalt oxide, which is clearly observed for the studied materials. An average reaction rate (rav), a conversion degree (xav) and TOF values (based on rav and H2 uptake values from H2-TPD data) for catalysts promoted only with cerium are vanishingly small. Nevertheless, the reaction rate as well as conversion degree, for the redCoCe(K2CO3) are twice higher than that for the redCoCe(KOH). This result is a direct consequence of the difference in the size of the surface area of an active phase (SCo) for the catalysts (Table 4). It is noteworthy that TOF values for both of the catalysts are similar, which indicates their similar surface activity. The barium addition causes the activity of the catalysts (rav, xav, TOF) to significantly increases. For catCoCeBa(K2CO3) over 20-fold increase of rav is observed at 400°C, whereas for catCoCeBa(KOH) the increase is even 38-fold. In the case of TOF, the values rise from 13 to 29-fold (depending on the temperature) and they are comparable for both catalysts. The increase of the average reaction rate may be a result of barium function in the promoted cobalt catalysts. From a comparison of the surface area of cobalt (Table 4) and TOF (Table 5 ) it can be inferred that an important role of barium in cobalt catalysts may be an electron modification of the active phase surface (Co). However, the barium addition can also have a positive influence on textural parameters of catalysts, which is particularly seen in the case of catCoCeBa(KOH) catalyst. The presented results are in good agreement with previous literature reports [18,19]. Similar effect of barium promotion was also observed for the Ba-Ru/C catalysts for ammonia synthesis [33]. The results of catalysts activity measurements after overheating (see Table 5 values in brackets) indicate that cerium and barium promoted catalysts are thermally stable. It means that keeping the catalysts under severe conditions for additional hours does not result in a loss of their activity. This corresponds well with our previous reports [18,19], which clearly showed that the CoCeBa catalysts exhibit a high thermal stability, i.e. the overheating at 600°C for more than 160h led to only a slight (approx. 10%) loss in their activity. But it should be pointed out that the overheating temperature (600°C) substantially exceeds the temperature of normal catalyst operation (about 400°C). This is very favorable from the point of view of the potential industrial application of the co-promoted cobalt catalyst. Another beneficial property of cobalt-based catalyst is its kinetic characteristic under conditions of high NH3 concentration. The NH3 synthesis reaction rates in relation to the bed volume of the iron catalyst (KM I) [19], ruthenium catalyst (Ba-Ru/C) [34] and cobalt catalyst (CoCeBa) [19] are compared in Fig. 5 . It can be clearly seen that the ruthenium catalyst has the most favorable kinetic characteristic, i.e. the decrease of its activity with increasing NH3 content in the gas phase is the lowest among the presented catalysts. This results in an increasing rRu/rFe ratio (see Fig. 5). The CoCeBa catalyst is more sensitive to changes of NH3 concentration in the gas phase than Ba-Ru/C catalyst and its kinetic characteristic is similar to that of the iron catalyst. However, it is more active than the iron catalyst (rCoCeBa/rFe >1 – see Fig. 5) and its advantage over the Fe catalyst gradually increases with increasing ammonia concentration in the gas phase. At approx. 1% NH3 in the gas the rCoCeBa/rFe ratio is 1.6, while at a concentration of 8% NH3 the ratio is 2.1. Extrapolating this trend towards even higher NH3 concentrations (approx. 15%) it can be assumed that the advantage of the CoCeBa catalyst over the Fe catalyst will be significantly larger. Considering the following sequence of the kinetic characteristics observed: Ba-Ru/C>CoCeBa>Fe, as well as the sequence of an estimated price of these catalysts: Fe<CoCeBa<Ba-Ru/C we postulate that the studied CoCeBa catalyst may be used as a supplement for the iron catalyst or as a substitute for the ruthenium catalyst. However, it should be used rather in that part of NH3 synthesis reactor, where conversion degree is high. Therefore, the application of cobalt catalyst as a supplement for the iron catalyst in lower part of the two-bed type reactor is considered as more reasonable then a total replacement of the entire Fe catalyst bed. 4 Conclusions In the investigated catalytic systems the use of various precipitating agents significantly influences the properties of materials obtained in the subsequent stages of their preparation (carbonate or hydroxide forms – oxide forms – oxides impregnated with barium salt). However, the differences in textural parameters, Co3O4 crystallite size (causing changes in a reduction process) or the surface area of the active phase of these materials decrease with progress of catalysts preparation. After the introduction of barium promoter and reduction the properties of CoCeBa systems become similar. X-ray diffraction measurements indicate that in some of the catalysts an active phase (cobalt) exists as a physical mixture of hcp and fcc phases, whereas some of them have polytypic structure. Nevertheless, these structural and initial textural differences in materials properties did not influence the final activity of the catalysts in ammonia synthesis reaction. Regardless of the precipitant used the studied cobalt catalysts promoted with cerium and barium exhibit similar surface area of an active phase, surface activity (TOF) and the average reaction rate in NH3 synthesis. However, the TOF values for the doubly promoted catalysts are about one order of magnitude higher than that for the catalysts promoted only with cerium. Therefore, it seems that not a type of precipitating agent used during preparation, but a composition of the studied promoted cobalt catalysts (i.e. the presence of Co, Ce and Ba) is more important factor influencing the activity of these catalytic systems. Hence, the choice of precipitating agent may be dictated by reasons of practical character – the use of KOH causes considerable inconvenience to filtration and washing of the precipitate obtained. In the case of potassium hydroxide the catalysts preparation process is much longer and more laborious compared to that with the use of potassium carbonate. coredata.dc:description: Cobalt catalysts singly promoted with cerium and doubly promoted with cerium and barium were prepared by co-precipitation using different precipitating agents, i.e. potassium hydroxide or potassium carbonate, subsequent calcination and impregnation. The obtained materials were characterized at each step of preparation using selected techniques: X-ray fluorescence (XRF), N2 physisorption, X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD), temperature-programmed reduction coupled with mass spectrometry (TPR-MS) and temperature-programmed hydrogen desorption (H2-TPD). The activity in ammonia synthesis was measured also under conditions close to the industrial ones (T=400–470°C, p=6.3MPa, H2/N2 =3:1). The materials obtained with the use of K2CO3 as a precipitant have better textural parameters (smaller Co3O4 crystallites) than the analogous materials obtained with the use of KOH. The differences in textural properties of the materials derived from KOH or K2CO3 as a precipitant decrease with a progress of catalysts preparation and finally the active phase surface area of the catalysts promoted with cerium and barium is similar. Regardless of the precipitating agent used the surface activities (TOF) and NH3 synthesis reaction rates for these catalysts are nearly the same. However, the TOF values for the doubly promoted catalysts are about one order of magnitude higher than that for the catalysts promoted only with cerium. Therefore, it seems that not a type of precipitating agent used during preparation, but a composition of the studied promoted cobalt catalysts is more important factor influencing the activity of these catalytic systems.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of precipitating agent on the properties of cobalt catalysts promoted with cerium and barium for NH3 synthesis obtained by co-precipitation
